newsitem.title: INDIA: Kashmir separatists say rights violations on rise.
newsitem.headline: Kashmir separatists say rights violations on rise.

text.p: Kashmir's leading separatist alliance on Thursday said human rights violations by Indian security forces had increased at an alarming rate in recent months, but authorities denied the allegation.

"The human rights violations, rape of our women and the killings at the hands of Indian security forces in Kashmir in recent months are at an all-time high," Umar Farooq, chairman of the All Parties Hurriyat (Freedom) Conference, said.
"The situation is alarming," he told a news conference.
The Hurriyat is an umbrella organisation banding together some 30 religious and political groups.
A senior Indian army official denied the charge.
"There are a lot of subversive people who instigate such reports," Lieutenant-General J.S. Dhillon told another news conference in Srinagar, summer capital of troubled Jammu and Kashmir state.
"We have taken much faster action in reported security excesses. In fact, four soldiers were sentenced for 10 years imprisonment for a rape case," Dhillon said.
Dhillon, who heads a unified command of different Indian security agencies fighting a separatist insurgency in Kashmir, is also a security adviser to the state government.

The Hurriyat accused security agencies of killing at least 818 people in the first four months of this year. "Over 141 people were killed in the custody of security forces during this period," Umar Farooq said.
According to an official spokesman, more than 700 people were killed in 174 bomb explosions and other militancy-related incidents during the first four months of the year.

"About some excesses committed by the security forces, I assure you that all cases have been investigated and wherever we have found that we required to take action, action has been taken," Dhillon said.
Dozens of guerrilla groups seeking merger with Pakistan or independence have been fighting Indian security forces in Kashmir since 1990.
More than 20,000 people have died in violence since then.
